title: Great Value
description: I normally use Mobil 1 full synthetic 5W 20 in my car. After seeing a review on youtube about this oil, I figured I would try it myself. Every other oil change, I send a sample to Blackstone-Labs in Ft. Wayne, IN for an analysis.  The Mobile 1 with a Mobil 1 filter always comes back with a great analysis report.  I did an oil change with Amazon Basics full synthetic and a Mobil 1 filter and sent an oil sample to Blackstone-Labs. Same thing, great report except a trace amount of fuel in the oil. This could be because of excessive idle time and has nothing to do with the Amazon Basics oil. I don't change my oil every 3,000 to 5,000 miles either. I go by when the computer on the car  tells me it's time to change the oil or when I get down to 3% oil life remaining. I put 9,868 miles on the Amazon Basics oil and it was still good. Todays oils are so much better than they were just a few years ago. The only way to tell if the oil you are using is good or bad is by doing an oil analysis. This will also let you know more about what is going on inside your engine, like, a leaky fuel injector(s) , antifreeze in your coolant, cylinder and bearing wear, viscosity, and if the filter you are using is working properly.  The Amazon Basics is a little cheaper than Mobil 1 and I don't have to drive to town to get it.

title: Excellent!  Highly recommend!
description:
I have regularly used Full Synthetic oils for awhile now.  I was hesitant to switch from Mobil1, so I searched on some reviews and tests done on this oil.  Everything looked good, so I moved forward.  Here are a few reviews and tests:  Project Farm https://youtu.be/a9DWGtXpYUc  and  Scotty Kilmer  https://youtu.be/Ye-5EyrwkOQ  The API "donut" shows it has been thoroughly tested in ways that neither of these two are able to do and passed.
I have now been using this oil for over a year.  I use 5w30 in my 2007 Land Cruiser (4.7 L v8), my 2011 Ford E250 EXT (5.4 L v8), and my mom's 2008 Lexus GX 470 (4.7 L v8).  I use the 0w20 in my daughter's 2009 Camry Hybrid (2.4 L 4cyl hybrid).  I change the oil and filter ~every 5000 miles (yes, I know you are supposed to be able to go 7000 miles... I'm just can't bring myself to do that.  I was a stickler for 3000 mile oil changes with conventional.)  The oil goes in clean and comes out dirty, just like it should.  I have never found any filings or metal flakes - or any other indicators of excessive wear.  It is REALLY hard to beat the price on this, and I am well pleased with the way it operates.  I do not plan to change anytime soon.  BTW, you should search for some testing on YouTube for oil filters, as well.  Wix, Napa (made by Wix), and Toyota seem to me to be top notch.  I've never had an issue with them.

ILSAC standards are constantly evolving and improving to meet changing industry demands.
